entries.text: chromatic writes about a nasty trap that one can fall in when using $_ in a construct that calls some other code that might change $_. It is especially a problem in map and grep where you have to use $_.

entries.text: Cosimo Streppone did not write about Perl in this article but he is using mytap, the MySQL version of TAP, the Test Anything Protocol. It is very nice to see how Perl helps the quality of the Opera browser through testing MySQL.
entries.title: Verifying MySQL behaviour with automated test suites and mytap

entries.text: Instead of Test Driven Development, Nitish Bezzala suggests Test Driven Learning. I think this can be a good idea though one needs to think how to introduce it and how to make sure the test framework does not hide problems or introduces new ones.
entries.title: Learning Perl with Testing

entries.text: While I agree with chromatic that too much mocking in tests is not healthy I am really not sure where does he get the idea that mocking is overused. The companies I visit never do mocking. OK, they usually don't do any testing and that's why they invite me and the only way to get some test up there is to mock half the universe. Or at least the external APIs. In any case, it would be interesting to check the level of mocking within CPAN.
entries.title: Mock Objects Despoil Your Tests
